awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Wintertime INvestigation of Transport, Emissions, and Reactivity (WINTER)
awd_abstract_narration:
This award will fund the deployment of a research aircraft in a study to observe wintertime pollution in the Northeastern United States.  While there have been a number of studies that have sampled atmospheric chemistry in the warm season, there have been relatively few studies in the cool season and none with the advanced instrumentation that the scientific community now possesses.  This is important because the processes that affect how much pollution is created and how far it travels depends significantly on water vapor and sunlight, both of which are dramatically different in summer and winter.  This study will examine how these processes work in cold temperatures and low sunlight and provide input to numerical modelers to help improve forecasts and provide guidance for policymakers on how to best reduce harmful air pollution events.

The Wintertime Investigations of Transport, Emissions, and Reactivity (WINTER) project will take place in early 2015.  The main goal is to provide observations needed to develop a deeper understanding of the chemical and physical processes which govern the spatial distribution of anthropogenic pollutants during winter.  The researchers argue that a majority of observations in polluted mid-latitude regions have been in summer, when plentiful sunlight and water vapor lead to the rapid oxidation of NOx and volatile organic compounds (VOCs) by OH.  In the winter months when OH concentrations are much lower and temperatures are colder, different oxidation pathways are expected to be more important. This leads to the slower oxidation of reactive pollutants such as nitrogen oxides, VOCs and sulfur dioxide, resulting in longer atmospheric lifetimes and therefore the transport of these species over wider geographic areas.  The colder winter temperatures also change the equilibrium gas-particle partitioning of semi-volatile species (e.g. HNO3) favoring the formation of particles and resulting in seasonal changes in dominant aerosol components. For example, studies have shown that inorganic nitrogen is a much higher component of the aerosol in the winter.  The three primary research objectives are:  1)  Characterize the chemical transformations of wintertime emissions via multiphase, nocturnal, and photochemical processes, 2) Assess the dominant mechanisms of secondary aerosol formation and quantify the geographical distribution of inorganic and organic aerosol types during winter, and 3) Constrain wintertime emission inventories of key pollutants for urban areas, power plants, and agricultural areas, and characterize their export over the North Atlantic.  In addition to the broader impacts stated above, a significant number of students would be involved in the field campaign and data analysis activities.  Outreach activities will include a media day, visits by K-12 students, and project updates through social media.

por.por_cntn:
Atmospheric aerosols have major effects on visibility, climate and human health. Field studies are important tools to study aerosol concentrations, sources, and evolution in the real atmosphere. However, the large majority of intensive field studies are conducted in warmer, more photochemically-active, times of the year. Winter has significantly lower temperatures; often more precipitation, thus wet deposition, and reduced solar radiation, which can significantly alter the processes that govern the production, processing, and lifetimes of aerosols. Although in the last couple decades there have been a number of wintertime studies of aerosol in Asia and Europe, very few have been conducted in North America, and none have been conducted in the Northeastern US. The lack of studies that target wintertime aerosol emissions and chemical transformations has resulted in a deficiency in our understanding of these atmospheric processes.

The primary objectives for the WINTER project were to characterize the main emission sources for both gas and particulate pollution to improve current inventories, assess overall gas/particle budgets, and constrain the importance of multiphase chemistry; and to advance our understanding of wintertime aerosol emissions and formation to better constrain secondary organic aerosol (SOA) formation and evolution. To this end, the National Center for Atmospheric Research (NCAR) C-130 aircraft flew 13 research flights, based out of Langley, VA in 2015. During these research flights, we sampled much of the eastern seaboard as well as off-shore outflow during both the daytime and nighttime. WINTER was a highly-collaborative field study, with participants from many universities and government institutions.

Our group deployed a state-of-the-art aircraft High-Resolution Time-of-Flight Aerosol Mass Spectrometer (HR-ToF-AMS) to measure non-refractory submicron particulate matter (PM1). These measurements allowed our group to focus on three important aspects of improving our understanding of wintertime emissions, sources, and chemistry: 1) The composition, and spatial, vertical, and temporal distributions of PM1; 2) The main sources and components of PM1, particularly OA and SOA; and 3) The evolution of OA and the formation of SOA as a function of photochemical age.

A unique, high-quality dataset was collected from the successful completion of the field deployment, followed by rigorous quality-control and data analysis. From these efforts, coupled with collaborations, the following key results were found:

  • The total PM1 concentration measured in WINTER was about 2.5 times lower than has been observed in a similar region during the summer.
  • Sulfate was most prevalent in the power plant rich Ohio River Valley region and off the northeastern coast.
  • Nitrate was spatially distributed similarly to sulfate, although tended to be less concentrated further offshore.
  • OA was more ubiquitous than nitrate or sulfate and showed significant concentrations from the outflow of several urban regions (PA, NJ, NY), as well as Atlanta and in the Ohio River Valley.
  • OA was surprisingly as oxidized in WINTER as has been observed in other regions of the US during spring and summer. 
  • A significant fraction of the OA (31%) was from biomass burning, presumably from residential wood burning activities.
  • An unexpectedly small amount of OA was primary (40%), compared to the secondary fraction (60%).
  • Modeling the OA oxidation using GEOS-Chem was underestimated by more than a factor of 3, when using the most recent emission inventories and default parameterizations. Those difference appear to be related to underestimation of SOA formation as well as assumed oxidation levels of SOA.
  • From a case study of urban outflow of the New York City metropolitan area over the ocean, the efficiency of SOA production was found to be as efficient (per hydroxyl radical exposure) as what has been observed in summertime Los Angeles, Mexico City, and Northeastern US. That suggests the processes governing urban SOA production in winter are similar to that in summer. However, when the actual rate of SOA production in the NYC metro area is evaluated using the estimated hydroxyl radical concentrations [OH] present, the SOA production takes twice as long, given a two-fold reduction in [OH]. Different methods, including a novel approach, were used for estimating photochemical age, which showed relatively consistent values.

The WINTER project was successful in many aspects. The results from this research will serve as a benchmark to improve model performance and the accuracy of current source inventories by constraining wintertime PM1 emissions, sources, and chemical processes. This research can also be used to improve parametrizations of OA aging in urban outflow during winter for chemical models analogous to those developed based on HR-ToF-AMS data acquired during the summer months. The research supported by this grant has been disseminated within the scientific community through several oral and poster presentations at major scientific conferences, workshops, and meetings; and has led to several collaborative peer-reviewed publications, one of which was led by our group. It has also provided a rich experience for a postdoctoral researcher through their active involvement and mentorship in cutting-edge and highly-collaborative atmospheric research.
